P.title: Will there be a significant discovery in robotics that contributes to the advancement of natural sciences by 2030?
P.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, a significant discovery in robotics has been made that contributes to the advancement of the natural sciences. A "significant discovery" is defined as a development in robotics technology or application that leads to a breakthrough in understanding, methodology, or application in any field of the natural sciences (e.g., biology, chemistry, physics, earth science). The discovery must be recognized as significant by the scientific community, evidenced by publication in a peer-reviewed scientific journal, citation in multiple subsequent research works, or acknowledgment by a reputable scientific organization. The advancement must be directly attributable to the robotics discovery and represent a clear departure from existing capabilities or knowledge. In the event of multiple discoveries, the question will resolve as Yes if at least one meets these criteria. Discoveries that are primarily advancements in computer science or engineering without direct application to the natural sciences do not count towards this question's resolution.

P.title: Will machine learning be used to predict election outcomes in any country with over 90% accuracy before 2030?
P.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, before January 1, 2030, a machine learning model is used to predict the outcome of a national election in any country with a population exceeding 1 million people, and achieves an accuracy rate of over 90% compared to the official election results. The prediction must be made public before the election occurs and must cover the majority of elected positions or the overall election result. The accuracy of the prediction must be verified by a reputable source, such as a major news organization (BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post) or an academic publication. P.title: Will France implement a nationwide carbon neutrality policy by 2030?
P.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, France has officially implemented a nationwide policy aimed at achieving carbon neutrality. The policy must encompass measures to significantly reduce greenhouse gas emissions across all sectors of the economy, including but not limited to energy, transportation, agriculture, and industry, with the goal of balancing emitted and absorbed greenhouse gases. Implementation is defined as the policy being enacted into law by the French government, with clear, actionable steps and timelines for achieving carbon neutrality. Confirmation must come from official government announcements or documentation. In the absence of a public announcement, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, Reuters, Bloomberg, New York Times, Washington Post) are sufficient. In the event of a partial implementation (e.g., limited to specific regions or sectors), the question will resolve as Yes only if there is a clear, government-confirmed plan for nationwide application.

P.title: Will China implement a comprehensive legal framework for regulating artificial intelligence by 2025?
P.body:
This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, China has officially implemented a comprehensive legal framework for the regulation of artificial intelligence (AI). The framework must cover at least the following areas: 
- Ethical use of AI
- Data privacy and protection
- AI in public surveillance
- Autonomous vehicles
- AI in healthcare
The implementation of such a framework must be confirmed by an official government announcement or documentation. In the absence of a public announcement, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, Reuters, Bloomberg, New York Times, Washington Post) are sufficient. 
For the purpose of this question, a "comprehensive legal framework" is defined as a set of laws or regulations that collectively address the ethical, social, economic, and technical aspects of AI deployment and use across multiple sectors.

Acknowledgment must come from at least one of the following authoritative sources: - The International Renewable Energy Agency (IRENA) - The International Energy Agency (IEA) - A major global energy conference or summit, specifically highlighting Germany's leadership in renewable energy technology. Leadership in renewable energy technology is defined by: - The creation and implementation of innovative renewable energy technologies that exceed current global standards. - Significant contributions to global renewable energy research and development. - A substantial increase in Germany's renewable energy capacity and production, leading the world in either total capacity or growth rate. In the absence of explicit acknowledgment from the above sources, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, Reuters, Bloomberg, New York Times, Washington Post) confirming Germany's status as a global leader in renewable energy technology will suffice. Temporary achievements or projects that do not indicate a sustained leadership position do not count towards this question's resolution.

P.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, the National Football League (NFL) has officially hosted a regular season or playoff game in a country that, at the time of the game, is under international sanctions by the United Nations, the European Union, the United States, or any other major international body. P.title: Will China become the leading country in quantum computing research impacting the natural sciences by 2030?
P.body:
This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, China is recognized as the leading country in quantum computing research with significant impacts on the natural sciences. Leading status can be determined by:
- The number of peer-reviewed scientific publications in quantum computing by Chinese researchers or institutions, compared to those from other countries.
- The establishment or operation of quantum computing facilities that are recognized as the most advanced in terms of computational capabilities or scientific breakthroughs.
- Recognition by international scientific organizations or panels as the leader in quantum computing research impacting the natural sciences.

Significant impact on the natural sciences must be evidenced by groundbreaking research findings or technological advancements in fields such as physics, chemistry, biology, and earth sciences, directly attributed to Chinese quantum computing research.

In the absence of clear international recognition, a consensus among reputable scientific publications (e.g., Nature, Science, IEEE Transactions on Quantum Engineering) and news outlets (e.g., BBC, The New York Times, Science Daily) will be considered sufficient.

P.title: Will the Bureau of Labor Statistics report a significant shift in employment within the renewable energy sector by 2025?
P.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, the Bureau of Labor Statistics (BLS) reports a significant shift in employment within the renewable energy sector in the United States. A "significant shift" is defined as an increase or decrease of at least 10% in the total number of employed individuals in the sector compared to the previous year's report. The renewable energy sector includes industries and jobs directly involved in the production, installation, and maintenance of renewable energy sources such as solar, wind, hydroelectric, geothermal, and biomass energy. The BLS's Annual Report on Occupational Employment and Wages will be the authoritative source for this determination. In the absence of a clear report from the BLS, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (e.g., Bloomberg, Reuters, The New York Times) will be considered sufficient. Temporary fluctuations due to seasonal hiring or short-term projects do not count towards this question's resolution.

P.title: Will an NBA player break the single-game scoring record by 2030?
P.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, an NBA player breaks the current single-game scoring record of 100 points, set by Wilt Chamberlain on March 2, 1962. Exhibition, pre-season, and All-Star games are excluded. The game in which the record is broken must be completed under the NBA's official rules without any disqualifications that could affect the game's outcome or the record's validity. In the event of a tie, where multiple players break the record in the same game, the question will resolve as Yes. The game must be part of the official NFL season schedule, and not a pre-season or exhibition game. Confirmation must come from an official NFL announcement or credible news reports from at least three major news organizations (e.g., ESPN, BBC, The New York Times, The Washington Post). In the event that sanctions are lifted on a country after the announcement of the game but before the game itself, the question will still resolve as Yes if the sanctions were in place at the time of the announcement. Temporary or partial sanctions specifically targeting individuals or entities within the country do not qualify; the sanctions must be country-wide.

P.title: Will an athlete competing in the Olympics break a world record in a natural sciences-related event by 2024?
P.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2024, an athlete competing in the Olympic Games breaks a world record in an event that is directly related to the natural sciences. For the purpose of this question, a "natural sciences-related event" is defined as any Olympic event that requires a demonstration of principles of physics, chemistry, biology, or earth sciences in order to achieve a record-breaking performance. This includes, but is not limited to, events in archery (physics of trajectory), sailing (aerodynamics and fluid dynamics), and shooting (ballistics). The breaking of the world record must be officially recognized by the International Olympic Committee (IOC) and the relevant international sports federation. In the event of a dispute over the classification of an event as "natural sciences-related," the resolution will default to the consensus of the scientific community. This question resolves as YES upon official confirmation of the record by the IOC and the relevant sports federation.

P.title: Will there be a major nuclear accident reported in the news by 2030?
P.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, a major nuclear accident is reported by at least three reputable news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post, Reuters). A "major nuclear accident" is defined as an event classified at Level 5 or above on the International Nuclear Event Scale (INES), indicating wider consequences beyond the immediate site of the incident. The accident must be confirmed by official sources or through detailed reporting by the aforementioned news organizations. In the event of conflicting reports about the severity of the incident, the question will resolve based on the consensus of coverage by the specified news organizations. Temporary safety incidents or events classified below Level 5 on the INES do not count towards this question's resolution.

P.title: Will a new vaccine for a major infectious disease be approved by the FDA by 2025?
P.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) has officially approved a new vaccine for a major infectious disease. A "major infectious disease" is defined as a disease that has caused significant morbidity or mortality in the United States or globally within the last 10 years, as reported by the World Health Organization (WHO) or the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). The approval must be for a vaccine that has not been previously available in the United States, and it must be intended for widespread use rather than limited to emergency authorization. The resolution will be based on official FDA announcements or documentation. In the absence of a public announcement, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post) are sufficient. The vaccine must be available for distribution within the United States to count towards this question's resolution.

P.title: Will a significant legal discovery in astronomy lead to a new international space law by 2030?

The new law must be officially adopted by an international governing body recognized for space affairs, such as the United Nations Committee on the Peaceful Uses of Outer Space (COPUOS) or an equivalent entity. P.title: Will Scott Alexander publish a groundbreaking paper on algorithmic game theory by 2030?
P.body:
This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, Scott Alexander (author of the Slate Star Codex and Astral Codex Ten blogs) has published a paper on algorithmic game theory that is recognized as groundbreaking by the academic community. A paper is considered "groundbreaking" if it introduces novel concepts, methods, or applications that significantly advance the field of algorithmic game theory, and is:

- Published in a peer-reviewed academic journal of high repute in the fields of computer science, mathematics, or economics.
- Cited by at least 50 unique academic works within two years of its publication.

In the absence of direct academic consensus, recognition by major organizations in the relevant fields (e.g., the Association for Computing Machinery, the American Mathematical Society, or the Economic Science Association) will be considered sufficient. The paper must be authored or co-authored by Scott Alexander and must explicitly contribute to the field of algorithmic game theory. Preprints, blog posts, or non-peer-reviewed publications do not qualify.

P.title: Will South Korea become the leader in global digital governance by 2030?
P.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, South Korea is recognized as the global leader in digital governance. Criteria for leadership in digital governance include but are not limited to: - Implementation of advanced digital services across government sectors. - Adoption of cutting-edge technologies in public administration. - Demonstrable impact of digital governance on improving public services and citizen engagement. - Leadership in international digital policy discussions and agreements. In the event of a tie or close competition with another nation, the question will resolve as Yes only if South Korea is clearly distinguished as the leader by the majority of the aforementioned sources. Edge cases, such as temporary leadership positions or recognition in a single aspect of digital governance, do not meet the resolution criteria.

P.title: Will NASA's commercial partnerships significantly boost the space economy by 2030?
P.body:
This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, NASA's commercial partnerships have led to a significant boost in the space economy, as evidenced by:

- A minimum of 50% increase in global space industry revenue compared to 2020, adjusted for inflation. This includes revenues from satellite launches, space tourism, space mining, and other commercial space activities.

- The establishment of at least one commercially viable off-Earth manufacturing facility or habitat, operational and generating revenue.

- The successful launch and operation of at least five significant new commercial space missions (e.g., satellite constellations, space tourism missions, asteroid mining operations) directly resulting from NASA's partnerships.

Significant boost will be determined based on reports from authoritative sources in the space industry, such as the Space Foundation, the International Astronautical Federation, or equivalent. In the absence of direct reports, credible coverage from major news organizations (e.g., BBC, The New York Times, The Economist) will be considered.

In case of ambiguity, the consensus of the scientific and commercial space community will be used to determine the outcome.

P.title: Will a study published before 2030 demonstrate a significant impact of climate change on soccer playing conditions worldwide?
P.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2029, a peer-reviewed study is published demonstrating a significant impact of climate change on soccer playing conditions worldwide. Significant impact is defined as changes that affect the health and performance of players, the scheduling and locations of matches, or the physical conditions of playing fields. The study must be recognized by a leading scientific organization or journal in the field of climate science, sports science, or a related field. In the absence of a single comprehensive study, a consensus among multiple studies published in reputable scientific journals may also satisfy this criterion. The resolution will rely on reports from authoritative sources such as the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC), World Health Organization (WHO), or major sports governing bodies like FIFA. In the event of conflicting reports, the majority consensus among these sources will determine the outcome. Edge cases, such as localized impacts not reflective of global trends, do not count towards this question's resolution.

P.title: Will a quantum computing breakthrough lead to a significant advancement in solving complex natural science problems by 2030?
P.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, a breakthrough in quantum computing results in a significant advancement in solving complex natural science problems, such as those in physics, chemistry, biology, or earth sciences. A "significant advancement" is defined as a solution or substantial progress on a problem that has been widely recognized as unsolved or intractable with classical computing methods. The breakthrough must be documented in a peer-reviewed scientific journal or recognized by a leading scientific organization or consortium. In the absence of a single defining event, a consensus among experts in the field, as reported by at least three reputable news sources (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post), will be considered sufficient evidence. The advancement must be directly attributable to the capabilities of quantum computing, rather than incremental improvements in classical computing or other technologies.
